column11: I have NO complaints so far, and am impressed with it's many features which are not difficult to understand even if I may never use them all. I especially like the 24mm wide angle, which is one of the main reasons I selected this camera. It is just the right (small) size and seems very well made. column2: Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS8 14.1 MP Digital Camera with 16x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column11: This is a terrific little camera. The images are crisp and clear. It is a good size for a pocket camera. Not too small so that it is hard to hold and not too large to stick in my pants pocket. I use it every day. Yesterday I took some pictures of a bald eagle perched high in a pine tree in my yard. The 16X zoom makes it possible for shots like that. I can zoom in even more when viewing the pictures on my laptop without having the pixels break up. I have a Canon S5 IS which has a 12X optical zoom and takes wonderful pictures but it is nearly the size of an SLR camera and is inconvenient for toting around regularly. This Panasonic takes equally good pictures (as far as I can detect) and is so easy to handle. I highly recommend this camera. Buying it through Amazon was so easy and I felt assured that if there were problems with the product, they would take care of me.

column2: Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS8 14.1 MP Digital Camera with 16x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column11:
I bought this for a friend of my wife who doesn't know the first thing about photography nor cameras. So of course I got to use it before her so I could acquaint her with it. I like it, but then again, I like all the Lumix-es (Lumixi) that i've used. I personally have a waterproof DMC-TS3. It's the reason I recommended this one for her.
It's a really good balance of user friendly and versatile. Not to intimidating for someone uninitiated.
So far, quality is wonderful. The price is right and she's very blown away. So I'm happy.
I'm not a professional but I know enough to know quality from crap.

If you really want a good review of this or ANY camera, I really suggest going to dpreview.com. They're REALLY thorough and far more reliable than any review you can get here. I always check out a camera there before I consider buying it.

column2: Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS8 14.1 MP Digital Camera with 16x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column10: Takes Nice Pictures But Defective Camera
column11: I bought this camera in July 2011 and it takes excellent pictures.  Recently it will not connect with the USB cable to my computer.  I called Panasonic and they told me it was probably a defective cable.  I bought a new one for approximately $10 including shipping.  The cable took a week to arrive and it still does not connect to my compouter.  I called customer service today and after tryimng for a half an hour it still does not work.  Since it is out of the one year warranty, I have to pay shipping and send it back with all the parts.  The repair costs $180 which is a joke since the new camera is only $230.  Fortunately my laptop has a card reader so I do not need to connect the camera to my computer.  Still, the camera is defective after very little use and the cost of repairs is crazy.  Let the Buyer Beware.

column2: Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS8 14.1 MP Digital Camera with 16x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column11:
The DMC-ZS8 is, or should I say 'was', a great camera. Unfortunately, this is the second Panasonic Lumix camera that we purchased that has failed on us.

I forget the model number of the first one, but it took wonderful photos for about 3 years, then the lens would not open completely. We liked the camera so much that we decided to spend $150 to have it repaired. The 'repaired' camera worked for about a year, maybe less, then failed again. Same problem - lens would not open completely. Waste of $150.

I searched for a replacement camera but I could not find anything at a reasonable price that measured up to the combination of Panasonic and Leica. So I bought the DMC-ZS8. It, too, WAS a great camera. But, it only lasted 15 months. Now it just displays 'System error (Focus)' on the screen. It doesn't do anything.

Panasonic customer service offered NO HELP because the 1 year warranty had expired. They want $180 to repair it!! (It only cost $150 new!!)

Let me just emphasize here that we do not abuse cameras or anything else that we own. We handle them very carefully.

I thought I would not be able to beat Panasonic electronics combined with a Leica lens. I guess I was wrong. 'Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me'. I will never buy another Panasonic camera, and will be unlikely to buy anything else from Panasonic again. If you are considering this camera, I would strongly urge you to look to another brand. I'm heading straight for Canon or Nikon.

column2: Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS8 14.1 MP Digital Camera with 16x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column11: I am a fan of Panasonic and have 3 of their cameras. I used to have 4 but my daughter fell in love with this one and adopted it. Although it's a bit large for a shirt pocket, it has an incredible (wide angle/telescopic) range and produces nice clear pics. Lots of features but works just fine on the automatic setting.

After about a year / year and half of regular usage, random black marks show up when using the video feature.  It has happened with all three of my cameras so I just assumed I was misusing it.  However, with my latest purchase, I went out of my way to care for it and it has never been dropped.  So when the black marks showed up, I totally lost faith in my beloved camera. column10: A Better Panasonic Lumix Digital Camera !
column11:
A Better Panasonic Lumix Digital Camera !

The Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS8 is a very good camera. The new camera has great new features.This new features can help you take better pictures! This year new features are fantastic. The DMC-z58 is packed with new features.

The new model DMC-ZS8 features a powerful 16x optical zoom lens.This lens has been redesigned. The new high-quality LEICA DC VARIO-ELMAR lens system is even more versatile with 24mm ultra wide-angle* to powerful 16x optical zoom.

The new and Powerful 16x Optical Zoom. This optical zooom gives you highly natural expressions from people and animals that you can't get close to. The camera can be used to film movies.It is designed to suppress noise while zooming.

The camera features a 3.0-inch, 230,000-dot High-resolution LCD.
The DMC-ZS8 is equipped with a 3.0-inch LCD . The big screen reflects fine details, making it easy to check the focus before shooting. It also serves as a photo and video viewer, allowing you and friends to enjoy viewing the still and motion images together.

The high-performance Venus Engine VI is incorporated in the DMC-ZS8. it enables the recording of beautiful images. An advanced noise reduction system in the Venus Engine VI applies noise reduction . Beautiful images with minimal noise can be reproduced for beautiful night shots or dimly lit indoor shots.

AF Tracking Subject Detection. Once you focus on your subject, the AF Tracking automatically tracks it until you press the shutter. When you're taking images of an active subject, like children or pets, this function eliminates the need to press the shutter button halfway down repeatedly to readjust the focus. The AF Tracking makes sure you don't miss those once-in-a-lifetime shooting opportunitie

This camera is portable. The camera Product Dimensions are 1.3 x 4.1 x 2.3 inches . You can travel with this camera. It is a very light camera. It only weights 7.4 ounces.

The Lumix ZS8 digital camera comes with many items.It has Battery Charger and Battery Pack. It comes with AV Cable, USB Cable. It comes with a Hand Strap. It includes a CD-ROM . Everything you need is included. You won't be disappointed !

column2: Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS8 14.1 MP Digital Camera with 16x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD (Black) (OLD MODEL)
column10: Good for photos, terrible for motion pictures
column11:
I used to have a DMC-ZS3, which was good, but didn't have a manual mode. The good thing about that is that you could take a motion picture up to the SD card limit. I switched to a ZS8 thinking that, if it's the new camera of the series, it must be better.

In some ways I was right. But the camera allows only 2Gb each motion picture since it doesn't have the AVCHD Lite mode. It means that where the old camera could film for one hour, the new one can film for 8 minutes!

I'm really disappointed and I don't recommend a camera that has this limitation. Don't buy it!

column10: Time will tell, but right now, props to Panasonic!
column11: I've had this camera for a few days now and have clicked off around a 100 pictures. I won't get into technical aspects, they have been 'done to death' in other reviews but for the price of this camera and the size of this unit, features it processes, weight, quality of photos, ease of use, and optical zoom capability I am impressed. I bought this to replace my Fuji Finepix S5700 which was becoming a chore to tote around and severely outdated. I wanted a 'pocketable' super zoom camera, something I didn't have to wear on a strap around my neck. After reading reviews of the ZS8 from all around the internet I felt this was my best choice and right now I am glad I chose it. I do have a concern about the on/off switch, the playback switch and the door over the battery and memory card. They all seem a little flimsy and I'm wondering how long they will last. If you're new to photography or graduating from a simpler camera to use this camera to it's full capacity it will take a little getting use to because of sheer number of features it has (it takes a 132 page manual to explain everything).

I don't know much about cameras but I do know what I want and this was not it. If you are like me with poor knowledge of digital cameras and you are looking for a good digital camera with good zooming feature, high megapixel that takes good video and takes good pictures at night time take a look at the Nikkon s8200 I bought it and I have to say I looooove it the pictures are just amazingly great and trust me the Panasonic DMC-ZS8 was not the only camera I tested.

column11: I purchased this camera to take pictures at my brother-in-law's 50th birthday party and even though I hadn't even tested it out prior to the party, it took BEAUTIFUL pictures! After my teenage son got his hands on it and played around with the various features, the pictures got even better.  I was even impressed with the zoom since I took several shots from the back of the room and they even looked sharp & crisp. So I was wondering how well the video feature would do, and I was surprised with how well it recorded children jumping up and down while 'dancing'. The capability of taking photos while simultaneously video recording is a PLUS! It's lightweight but packed full of nice features and 'user-friendly' buttons. I still haven't figured out what else this camera can do but I'm already amazed with what I do know about it.  I HIGHLY recommend this camera!

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column11: Got the camera in late June. Takes very nice pictures as long as lighting as adequate. It doesn't do well with low light. Or maybe I just didn't have long enough to figure it out because within a month I took the camera on vacation to Florida...in a nice padded case.  I did have it out on the beach the first day for all of 5 minutes or so.  It wasn't windy.  I wasn't near the water.  It was in the case - came out to take a few pictures - and went back in because the rain was coming so we left as soon as we got there.  We went from there to Epcot where I took a number of pictures before sitting down that evening to watch a musical show.  I was zoomed in fairly close and had taken maybe a half dozen pictures when the lens suddenly went blurry as if the camera had lost focus.  Lens kept going in and out repeatedly trying to regain focus and then I was prompted to power off and restart the camera.  Once I did I got the dreaded focus error that several others have talked about.  Nothing helped - not powering off, not removing the battery, nothing.  Each time I power it back on the lens automatically retracts all the way into the camera then extends all the way out and the error appears again and the camera shuts off.  It was not jarred and nothing got in it.  I was very careful due to the comments I'd read already but hello, it's a compact camera with a powerful zoom, not something made for a portrait studio. It's made to take with you when you live life.  Mine lived a month and now I'm sending it in and hoping it will be covered under warranty.

column10: HDR is also limited and flash is easy to partially cover while shooting
column11: Zoom is impressive, but f stop range is very limited.  Only goes to f 8 which limits focal range and shutter speed options.  HDR is also limited and flash is easy to partially cover while shooting.  Stability works well and picture quality is OK for such a compact camera. Recommend carrying 2 spare batteries if taking many pictures during the day.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column11:
Lumix ZS50 Digital Camera
Manufacturer: Panasonic
Amazon price: $397.99

The Panasonic LUMIX ZS50 is a new, feature-rich, compact, super-zoom camera that you can carry in your pocket. It was introduced at CES (Consumer Electronics Show) in January, 2015. If I were to describe my perfect camera, I would describe it just this way. I dont want to lug around a heavy bag and lots of gear, but I still want a great camera. As a longtime Lumix user I started with the TZ9 and as technology improved, moved to the ZS20. The new ZS50 has some remarkable improvements and enhancements. The three new features that convinced me were: a 2.0-inch live viewfinder so you can look through the cameras lens instead of squinting at the LCD screen when out in the bright sun, a 30X (30 times!) optical zoom, and a new, 12.2-megapixel high-sensitivity MOS sensor for enhanced low-light photography.

The camera includes built-in Wi-Fi connectivity that allows wireless transfer of your images to your computer or for display on an appropriate TV. I discovered a stunning feature when I started learning the cameras wireless capabilitiessmartphone integration! Panasonic has developed an Apple iOS and an Android app. Pairing the camera with your phone or tablet can be initiated by Wi-Fi or with its built-in NFC sensor. With the app, you can see what the camera sees on your iPhone or iPads screen. In addition, you can control the cameras zoom and exposure and fire the shutter from the app. For instance, imagine placing the camera on a tripod near a bird feeder and taking photos of the activity while you monitor them from a distance on your iPhonehands-free, remote photography.

At $400, the ZS50 is not a budget point-and-shoot, it is a precision-built, quality camera with a Leica 24-720mm Vario-Elmar lens. This lens allows ultra wide-angle shots as well as an astonishing 30X optical zoom. In Macro mode you can get as close as 3mm for your subject. When you are out in bright sunlight and have difficulty seeing the LCD screen, you can use the Live View Finder with its clear, bright 1,166-dot resolution. The camera can be set so that its sensor will only turn the viewfinder on when your hold it up to your eye. The camera incorporates a state-of-the-art O.I.S.+ (Hybrid Optical Image Stabilization Plus) 5-Axis system for capturing jitter and shake-free images.

This is a feature-rich camera. Its 46-page manual contains basic information and the manual on the included CD, is a whopping 306 pages. The ZS50s settings can be personalized in dozens of ways. You can easily feel overwhelmed as there are almost too many features and choices. However, if you are diligent, youll end up with a camera that is customized to your own photography requirements. There is a large knurled control ring around the lens barrel that can be rotated for zooming, setting aperture, shutter speed, focus, and other adjustments. Rotating this control ring is done with one hand and feels very natural compared to fiddling with tiny knobs and switches. The ZS50 includes a fast 240fps Auto Focus. There is almost no lag here so you wont miss a good shot while the camera is calculating and adjusting focus.

The camera has a variety of creative features that I dont use but they are available if you want to try them. There is a Creative Retouch feature, 15 Instagram-like filters, an auto-leveling setting (probably intended for use when video recording). There is also a strange selfie Jump Shot function that will fire the shutter at the apogee of a jump if you have a connected smartphone in your pocket when you jump.

My interests lie in still photography, but this camera also takes very smooth 1,920 x 1,080 full HD video utilizing its stabile Venus Engine. The recording is done in AVCHD Progressive format. Birds and other rapidly moving objects can be captured with clarity.

An intriguing feature for me is time-lapse. You can set the frequency of exposures and the result is an MP4 video file. Shoot a sunset at 10-second intervals, or an approaching thunderstorm, or a construction site from dawn to dusk. With the high-sensitivity MOS sensor, you can even shoot the stars.

This is a versatile, well-built camera. It has an astonishing array of features. Ive had many years of Lumix experience and Im seriously impressed with the new ZS50. In the iA (Intelligent Auto) mode, all you need to do it aim and shoot with excellent results. But if you are a semi-pro, youll have most of the big, DSLR features at your fingertips even though the camera is tidy and compact.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: with lots of bells and whistles to have fun with, especially the built in photo enhancer built ...
column11: This is one superb travel camera which does just about anything and very well indeed. 12 mp is all one needs in this small package. Fast shutter release, fast focus, with lots of bells and whistles to have fun with, especially the built in photo enhancer built in. Excellent software, excellent packaging. The eye viewfinder is well placed, and bright. In sunny conditions, this feature is really needed.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: Most impressive point-and-shoot that I carry with me
column11:
This is my initial experience of the Lumix DMC-ZS50K digital camera. I have been using digicams since the Sony Mavica came out. I love photography, not in a professional level but as a hobby and they are a big part of our lives as a family. This is one impressive camera for a point-and-shoot. I either lug along my DSLR or just shoot with a smartphone. For convenience I will go with the smartphone. But if I know I would be going to a trip to a place where we would shoot a lot of memories, a dedicated cam is the only way to go. The Lumix is small enough to carry along with my DSLR bag. It is small and the shape and profile is conservative enough with no awkward protruding lens. It is easy to slip in one of the pockets. Either as a backup or a camera to just grab and shoot, it performs quite well.

There are so many features that it will take you weeks to familiarize with all of them. For a quick shot, you can go to full auto modes. For more creative shots you can select manual and even does manual zooming. The Leica lens has a monster 30X optical zoom. It has an awesome stabilizer but for 30X you may still need a tripod. Panorama and shooting videos all benefit from the same stabilizer that creates seamless stitches and panning.

If you misses the viewfinder, the ZS50 has the best of both worlds. A large LCD screen which I use often for shooting high def videos or the viewfinder which I am accustomed for shooting stills.

If you cannot wait to send a picture to a friend, a family or to social media, the WiFi function becomes real handy. Download the app to your phone and fire it up. Soon you can send pictures or even videos into your phone. The interface is simple and easy. You can then send it anywhere you want.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: I got it because I wanted a small camera with both a viewfinder and a super zoom that could go everywhere and this fills the ...
column11:
I received my ZS50 from Amazon on Easter Sunday - yes really, delivery on Easter! - and I have been playing with it ever since. I got it because I wanted a small camera with both a viewfinder and a super zoom that could go everywhere and this fills the bill very nicely. Color and general picture quality is quite good for a small camera, although it could be sharper, for my taste, especially at full zoom.I generally shoot in P,S, or A so I can adjust the settings as needed. Because I like to underexpose I often set the EV down by at least a third. I don't shoot raw, but this still allows me to tweak both the brightness and the sharpness of my JPEGs in Photoshop. However many people will find this unnecessary as the pictures in automatic are usually very pleasing.
Some suggestions that work for me: 1) Get a neck strap if you use the camera for hiking. This keeps it convenient to use and avoids the issue of pocket lint (or whatever, unless there's a dust storm) from getting into the unsealed camera. I got mine several years ago from Polaroid and it has the advantage of releases (I'm not sure what to call them, pinch clasps?) on both sides of the strap so it can easily be taken off from the camera body without undoing the whole thing. 2) This suggestion is stolen from another reviewer and again addresses the "lint" issue while being very practical: when carrying the camera in a pocket or purse, take the neck strap off (if you use one) and put the camera in a sandwich bag. I add to that protection by first putting it in the thin envelope it came packed in. Not elegant, but convenient. 3) On an entirely different subject: if you use the macro setting - it's very nice - and switch to the macro closeup focus, remember to take it off when you're done. Otherwise you'll be limited to 3X zoom instead of 30X in most other settings. It drove me nuts and took me forever to figure out what I was doing wrong when this happened to me. 4) Unless you know that point and shoot is all you want to do, download the manual for advanced usage (or some such nomenclature.) It's not perfect, but it's a lot better than the alternative.
If you've read through all this, you can tell I really like the camera for what it is. While it will never replace my Olympus E-M1, it will go places I could never easily take my Oly - and already has.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: About Viewfinder, LCD Screen, Burst & RAW
column11:
ELECTRONIC VIEWFINDER: The ZS50 has a very good 1166k dot viewfinder through which you can see clear details. For those who wonder how this compares with the ZS40, the resolution is 5 times higher. 1166k versus the former 200,000k. The viewfinder of the ZS50 is very usable while the viewfinder of the ZS40 was mainly for marketing.

Most of the cameras that I have had over the years had a viewfinder and I much prefer to use it because framing photos is much easier for me than when holding the camera away from my body. I'm using it almost exclusively with this camera and very pleased.

Also for anyone thinking of upgrading from the ZS40, another improvement is the larger grip. This makes the camera easier to hold when using the viewfinder.

When I first looked through the viewfinder what I saw was not clear and sharp. However, I gave the wheel for the diopter that is right next to the viewfinder tiny turns until what I saw was clear and sharp. The difference was huge.

A neat new feature is the eye-detection sensor that automatically switches to the viewfinder as it nears your eye. No need to push a button to switch as was necessary with the ZS40. The button is still there, but not needed.

What you see on the LCD screen will also be seen when you look through the viewfinder. For example, if you are using the 'level gauge' to be sure the camera is straight, you will see the level indicator when looking through the viewfinder same as if you look at the screen

Even if you prefer to use the LCD screen, practice with the viewfinder because it is very helpful when following the movement of distant objects and to give more support when you are zoomed out. When the camera is held in both hands and pressed against your forehead it is more stable than when held away from the body.

Also, the viewfinder is very handy when the LCD screen is hard to read because of the sun.

Having a useable viewfinder gives this camera a big advantage over its rivals.

LCD SCREEN: The resolution of the screen has been increased to 1,040k dots, a small improvement over the 920,000 dots of the ZS40.

The screen is pretty good in varying light conditions, but if you have trouble in the direct sun, or to lessen the chance of future trouble in the sun, there are some things you can do:

1. Press the 'Menu' button, then select 'Setup'. Click on it and scroll down to 'Monitor Display' . Press the arrow that opens the choices and move the 'brightness' indicator (yellow) all the way to the right. I suggest you do that anyway and just leave it there.

2. If more needs to be done, scroll down one more line to 'Monitor Luminance'. Open to the options and put it on ' Auto Power Monitor' {A*. Leave it there until times you need more help than go back and change the setting to 'Power Monitor' [*. If even that isn't enough, use the viewfinder.

BURST MODE: When there is any kind of action, this is much better than taking single shots. You don't have to anticipate the exact moment something is going happen, you take a bunch of rapid-fire photos and pick out the best ones. Action is not just sports it can be children playing, a child learning to ride a bike, puppies playing, etc.

A burst mode of 10 fps (frames per second) is a big marketing point for this camera. But it is misleading. You can only shoot 10 fps when the camera is in the IA mode (Intelligent Auto) and you can only get six shots before the camera must reload, so to speak. For this reason, unless you know the exact second when something significant will occur, you are not likely to make much use of this setting. In this setting, focus is fixed with the first shot

Also when in the IA mode you have the option of 6 fps. When in this setting the camera keeps focusing and shooting as long as you keep pressing the shutter button. I have gotten about 30 shots in this setting and could have gotten more. But I didn't get 6 fps, it was closer to 4 fps. However, the fps would have been closer to 6 if I had shot fewer photos. It starts at 6 then tapers off as the camera processes the previous shots.

In all modes, including P, A & S, you can shoot 3 fps and will get about 3 fps. Again, the camera will keep shooting as long as the shutter is pressed and refocuses between shots. I have shot as many as 40 when in 'P' mode of a car moving away from me and the focus stayed pretty good and the fps was about 3 for the entire 40. I good have kept shooting at the same fps, but the car turned a far corner,

I am quite pleased with the burst mode. There are cameras that will do better than this one, but in this price range it does a very satisfactory job. I am especially pleased with how well it keeps focused when when shooting at 3 frames per second. To test this, I sat at a street corner where I could look down the street. When a car or motorcycle started down the street, I focused on the car/motorcyclist and started shooting until it turned a corner or it didn't make sense to continue. I could then look at the photos on my computer and check the focus. I was quite pleased that even after 20 shots the object I had focused on was still in focus. Reinforcing that were a couple of shots where a woman started crossing the street in the distance between me and the car. She was not in focus in the photos, but the car was. I did another test focusing on a distant car approaching me. The photos were sharp all the way.

You can also shoot in bursts when shooting RAW using the 3 fps setting, but I only get about 1.5 fps when I did again partly because of the number of images shot during the burst and partly because the RAW files are bigger than the JPEG files.

RAW: Many travel zooms do not offer RAW as an option. My Canon SX700 doesn't for example.

The debate about whether to shoot RAW or JPEG has been going on for a long time. There are reasons for both, including that RAW files contain more details but require processing by software to make them fully useable, while photos shot in JPEP are useable as they come from the camera, having gotten some processing in the camera. (Though they can often be made even better by post-processing).

However, what is important to know is that even though this camera is new, software support for RAW files from the camera are already widely available, including, after installing the update which you will get from the software, Photohop Elements, Corel PaintShop, Photoshop and Lightroom. There is no need to download the RAW converter on the CD that comes with the camera if you are using one of these photo editing programs. They are all better than the software on the CD.

Because the camera's sensor is so small you can't retrieve as much shadow or highlight detail as on a camera with a larger sensor, but you can adjust white balance, sharpening and noise. The RAW files also contain more color information than do JPEGs

.

column11:
The camera does everything that is supposed to do. The long range lens works well and most pictures can be enlarged to 8x11 and some to 13x19. The battery power is fine, but another battery is a necessity if you are taking pictures all day. The flash is in a bad spot and it is easy to block it with your finger. . Be sure to check the lighting on flash pictures. Also, the on/off button can be bumped easily if you put the camera in a small case. The various settings are a little hard to find since the buttons have many uses and are not double marked. However, we all have favorite settings and those can be easily remembered.
I love the camera because of the size and the ability to adapt it for different picture opportunities. It does not replace my DSLR, but when you do not want to carry a heavy camera, it certainly fills the bill. I have read other reviews. Some claim the pictures are soft. I do not find that to be the case. I am very happy with the picture quality. I would highly recommend it.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: Great Zoom, Poor Build Quality & Flash Placement
column11:
First off, I am a Panasonic Camera fan. I have several & this is the only one where I felt immediate disappointment when I opened the box. I received the camera Saturday. I can't seem to get past the build quality & the fact that the flash is in a really bad place.

CONS:
1. Build Quality. The camera is all plastic & looks almost like a toy. I bought the Silver. I suggest the Black. Maybe it will look better. If I were to keep it I would purchase a Square Trade Warranty as I have doubts about its durability.
2. Flash. The flash is in a very awkward place right where you grip the camera. You will have to be very mindful every time the flash is used & check finger positions. I have very small hands & it is awkward for me. If you have big hands it may be a problem.
3. Battery Charger. There isnt one? There is a charging cable that you can wall charge or PC charge while the battery is inside the camera. My other Panasonics came with a charger & a cable. I think Panasonic went econo with this feature too. (I realize you can buy a charger & additional batteries).

PROS:
1. Lightweight. It is small & lightweight. It will easily fit in a purse or pocket.
2. Zoom is great. However, get the closest shot that you can. If you crop the photo it is going to be grainy.
3. Photo quality. It's OK. In my opinion Its a little better than cell phone quality. The sensor is a 1/2.3 & most cell phones are a 1/3.2. However, you dont get a 30X Zoom with a cell phone (which is what attracted me to this camera.)
4. Viewfinder. I like the viewfinder & the fact that its automatic when you put your eye to it.
5. Settings. There are lots of settings much like other Panasonic Cameras.
6. WiFi. I didnt try to use as I plan on returning the camera.

I usually shoot in Auto, Program, or Scene modes (easy modes). I want an easy to use, lightweight camera, with a decent zoom to put in my purse. I thought this was the one. However, the build quality & flash placement is such a turnoff for me that Im planning on returning this camera. I will stick with my trusty ZS7 that Ive had since it was brand new. It only has a 12X Zoom, no viewfinder, no WiFi but its built a whole lot better & my finger doesnt block the flash.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column11:
Finally, a walk around camera I like. Professionally I use my Canon 7D Mark II, but I wanted something pocket sized. First, I wanted an eye level viewfinder. Most point & shoots don't have one. The Lumix gives you the option of switching between eye level or the LCD. Next the image quality is very good for 12 megapixels. Using a medium file size, I can enlarge posters to more than 100% with any noticeable degradation in the image.
The menu is extremely user friendly, and gives you the usual choices of A, S, M etc. I use manual mostly on my Canon because I want total control. The Lumix adjusts ISO automatically, as I like to use it with shutter preferred at 1/125. With its built in stabilization, I am guaranteed to get sharp images. For the Lumix I would never use flash. Natural light is always best. The price is good. The build is solid. And it focuses quickly too.
And last, but not least, a Leica lens!

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)

column11:
this has some great features! first and foremost-the zoom 30X is amazing!
photo quality is generally very good and a definite step up from my other panasonic camera of a few years ago.
i do like the viewfinder. there are lots of settings for each way of taking a photo, that takes a little bit of time to sort out.
be careful and check your settings once in a while to be sure the rotating selector on top doesn't change without you realizing it.
it is fast to start up and e ready to capture photos. the video is terrific and i like being able to zoom quietly during recording. battery time is great.
it fits in your pocket as advertised. i am not disappointed and looking forward to using it for a while.
i don't use the RAW setting, and turning it off saves memory space.
happy photo shooting!

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: The good news I use them
column11:
I'm not a well individual. I buy toys. The good news I use them. So far, under easy conditions, I've shot about 200 pics with this latest of my Lumix cameras. I THINK, and know it could be fooled by the name, that the Leica lens matters. I suspect that problems some might have with this camera may be underestimating it. Just because you have 700 MM in your hands, even with stabilization, does not mean you no longer need a tripod or solid support at 700 mm. I love this camera. Because of my shopping illness, I have a number of options. I've learned that a view finder and not just a rear-screen is essential. Mandatory. I have a crossover Leica. It takes better pictures, and cost double. Well now, triple almost. It is larger. I love it. I keep grabbing this Lumix to be within arms-reach when I'm on "bird alert." I also have rather large hands, and even with this camera being pretty small, I find it comfortable.
It has a very handy feature I've had before and love. When you put your eye to the viewfinder, the screen display automagically switches to the viewfinder. I really get annoyed by having to push a button to go from screen-view to viewfinder view. I'm easily annoyed I know.

Problems? of course. The knob that rotates (some have said the ink wears off, but I don't know yet) for selecting options on menus and the like rotates too easily. I end up changing things I did not intend to change.
Basically, once again, Lumix w/ Leica glass has put out a camera that delivers GREAT bang for the buck. Does my BIG Sony with a dedicated 100 mm macro lens, 24 megapixels, full frame chip get a better image? Sure. Does it fit in my pocket? Not as well. Can I take a real full moon picture with it? Happily, for the first time in my life yes. BUT I love this Lumix. It is a bit larger than the pocket-sized Lumix before it, but that one did not have a viewfinder. The 500 or so mm was fine. The image was fine. The size was astonishing for what it delivered. BUT, shoot in daylight? A viewfinder is a good thing.
This camera deserves respect. If the care that one might put into shooting with a large camera with a 700 mm lens is put into this low-key gem, the results will, I think , astonish.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: Excellent little pocket camera with an impressive feature set
column11:
I've been looking for a good quality point-and-shoot light-weight camera that fits in my pocket, has a long zoom, has a good viewfinder, one that travels easily, and not too costly. Turns out there aren't many choices that fit all these criteria. I enjoy photography, am a highly experienced photographer although not a pro, and have a really good camera with interchangeable lenses, etc. which I use when I want to get top quality pics and need to have a lot of control over focus, depth of field, mounted flash, etc. However, when traveling by air, hauling all that equipment around, taking up space in carry-on luggage, etc. tends to make me leave the really good camera at home. With pocket cameras I've used, I really miss having a viewfinder. I find them awkward to hold steady, and difficult to see on the backside LCD panel exactly what I'm getting in bright light or when I need to follow and catch fast moving objects (e.g., flying birds), particularly when the zoom is extended. I've been frustrated when I can't get the pics I want with those pocket cameras.

So I went out on a limb, spent a little more than I had intended, and got the new Panasonic Lumix ZS50, which I preordered. I seldom buy new models of anything when they first come out, so for me this was a bit of a gamble. However, I have been pleasantly surprised so far with this little camera. It has an amazing feature set for something that really does fit in my pocket, has a good viewfinder and plenty of zoom. I have not given it a true test yet, taking thousands of pics under a wide range of lighting and distance conditions, so I will have to report back later.

What I like so far:
- camera takes good pictures in the auto mode under most conditions
- viewfinder works well in bright light conditions, and switches on automatically when you hold it up to your eye
- zoom and focusing are relatively quick and quiet
- the steady shot feature works well, especially in shooting video
- flexibility and control in non-auto modes (e.g., program mode when I want more control over depth of field, etc.)
- several different focusing and exposure methods
- ability to save images in RAW format as well as JPEG
- the right hand grip feels fairly secure for such a small camera

What I don't like so far:
- viewfinder is off-center when holding the camera, compared with what I'm used to with larger cameras, so I can't grip it as securely with my left hand (because my nose is in the way) BUT I love having that viewfinder anyway!
- lots of MODES in the menu system for settings (I eventually found that I needed to switch to program mode in order to find settings I was looking for, e.g., to save pics in RAW format, change focusing methods). Can be confusing at times, a bit of a learning curve.
- the LCD display sometimes suddenly turns off and then back on, which had me baffled initially when playing back pics. Turns out I had moved a finger too close the the viewfinder, which fooled the camera into auto-switching to the viewfinder.
- when taking flash pictures, it's too easy to partially block the flash somewhat on the right side, which casts a shadow--just something I'll need to get used to by gripping a little differently on the right side (I've had this problem with other pocket cameras that don't have pop-up flashes). Works fine when I move my fingers down on the right-side grip a little.
- when doing the wi-fi setup, I could not enter user names or passwords that had spaces in them--I am stumped on this, and cannot understand why Panasonic would not allow selection of the 'space' character!!!
- wi-fi will not transfer pics in RAW format, so have to use cable or take out memory card and plug into my computer--again, why? Granted 15 Mb per pic will take a lot longer to transfer than smaller JPEGs.
- cannot charge battery outside of camera and must use Panasonic's cable
- not sure yet whether 12 megapixel sensor will be enough resolution for severely cropped pics, printed at 8x10 in. or larger

All in all, this is hands-down the best pocket camera I've owned and used. Why not 5 stars? I'll need to really give it the "road" test by taking thousands of pics under a wide range of conditions. Haven't had time to do this yet, and plan to edit this review later when I have.

Added Comments: April 26, 2015

I've changed my rating to 5 stars now, after taking several hundred pictures under varying conditions. Here are my further observations:

- Indoor pictures with flash turn out fairly well. There are still sharp background shadows from objects illuminated by the flash, but that is to be expected with a direct flash (compared to one with indirect lighting, e.g., by bouncing light off the ceiling).
- outdoor pictures are quite good on the whole. The 30x zoom certainly provides some additional flexibility, and I have not had issues with camera shake when the zoom is extended.
- the one very challenging condition I was somewhat disappointed with was photographing fast flying pelicans at a distance on a very windy, overcast day. Many of the photos of the birds were taken at distances of several hundred yards up to half a mile, using the zoom extended out to 30x. I WAS able to track the birds relatively easily using the viewfinder. When later viewing the images with significant cropping on a flat screen HDTV, clarity of the images left something to be desired--a bit fuzzy on the edges of the birds against the cloudy sky. This is a very challenging set of circumstances--even with a good DSLR camera with a long telephoto lens, it would be challenging to get high quality pics. All in all, the Panasonic ZS50 did a remarkable job, considering the distance involved, with background of a cloudy sky, the speed of the flying flock of birds, and the fast panning required. The severely cropped images of the high flying birds still allowed my wife to identify them as white pelicans by comparing with pictures in her bird book.
- I took some pics of blossoms and flowers with the camera just a few inches away, using the close-up focus setting on a sunny and very windy day. These came out exceptionally well. I was very pleased with the results. The pictures were quite stunning on a flat screen TV.

All in all, I am quite impressed with this pocket camera, and enjoy taking pictures with it, since it is so light, has a decent viewfinder, and takes good photos. I use the Program mode mostly, rather than the Auto mode. Of course, I can get great pics with my really good camera, but I've invested roughly 4x as much for the body, lenses and external flash unit. On the other hand, this Panasonic ZS50 fits in my pocket, is easy to use, and costs a lot less.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column11: Fairly intuitive camera at the basic level of use, fortunately, because mine did not come with an owner's manual in English (only Spanish), and I got the camera just before leaving the country for a 41/2 week vacation.  I mostly used the "intelligent" function, and the pictures seem to be coming out pretty good, even with backlit situations.  Being an old 35 mm SLR user, I mostly use the viewfinder, and I have been very pleased by the image quality that it has.  Video quality seems very good, as well.  I hope to be able to learn how to take advantage of the manual options, now that we are back home.  I haven't notice any quality issues that a few other reviews have complained about.  The body is plastic, rather than metal (like our older Panasonic point and shoot had), but that seems to be the standard for the point and shoots these days.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column11: Fantastic Camera and Camcorder.  It takes great images and has a lot of extra useful features.  I would highly recommend this product to everyone.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: Immediate problems and wearing off of painted icons on toggle switch after first use
column11: After comprehensive research, I found this camera to be rated the best in it's class for all around performance.  The only real negative review I read was that the paint on the round toggle switch to change modes and shooting preferences, wore off.  I figured this was an isolated incident as there was only one complaint of this.  I purchased the camera and I decided to take this camera for a spin on my trip to Central America.  After the second day of shooting, the paint on the toggle switch began to wear off.  By the 4th day of shooting, the paint was completely gone, leaving just a blank round toggle switch!  Perhaps this was from perspiration or sunscreen or just the friction from my finger on the switch.  I contacted the company I purchased it from (through Amazon) and was informed it was past the 30 day warranty so I called Panasonic and they told me to send it into their repair center in texas and the part would be replaced.  The paint is not supposed to come off that easily and he felt maybe there was a "printing issue?!"  I of course have to pay for the shipping but the 1 year warranty covers the repairs.  In addition, I had several occasions where the plastic 2 door shutter would not close all the way to protect the lense.  After shooting, I would close the camera and the shutter would stay partially open, exposing the sense to potential damage.  This problem resolved on it's own after turning the camera on and off multiple times but I assume it's going to be an intermittent issue.  For such a promising technological camera, it's made very poorly.  If you do decide to purchase this camera, I would HIGHLY suggest fashioning some sort of clear coat plastic cover over the round toggle switch to protect the letters from wearing off so easily.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: The flash is in the wrong place. It is ...
column11: The flash is in the wrong place. It is next to impossible to take a picture without one of your fingers blocking or partially blocking the flash. It should be on the other side. Yes, if you think about it and make a conscious effort to avoid the flash with your fingers, you can do it. But who wants to go through that every time they take a picture?

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column11:
This is a great camera. Not a perfect camera but a great one. In reality, it's probably a 4 to 4.5 star camera but because it has a view finder as well as a lcd screen on back, for me, that's worth an extra star. I've never been good at walking around like a zombie, arms out straight staring blankly. I have however learned to use view finders with one eye, while using the other to keep me aware of my surroundings. I don't like being annoyed by glowing screens at darkened venues like concerts and other night time events. It's rude folks...stop it! I have an FZ18 as well as an FZ70 for more serious stuff. But I like the convenience of a small point and shoot with a view finder eyepiece. I also have a collection of older high end 35mm SLRs

The basics:
I purchased the all black ZS50 which is the 'K' model I believe. Mine was set for Caracas time zone and came with Spanish Language owners manual. But that's okay as I am bi-lingual.
Camera fits in a man's dress shirt pocket. It is fairly solid (heavy) but not so much as to be objectionable. Flash is built into front top of camera and does not pop up All knobs and buttons are well placed. Holding and using the camera feels normal and natural. ( I have perfect vision, no glasses or contacts to get in the way) Electronic viewfinder is bright, color accurate and proportionally accurate to area captured by lens. Leica glass optics. Zoom is fast and easy to use. 30x optical and mine goes out to 57x electronically. For some reason, I though it had a 60x digital zoom but mine only ('only' LOL) goes out to 57x. Having started in the 1950s shooting two and a quarter inch large format negative film, I have to chuckle and at the same time be amazed by what these little gems can do.
I'll let you read all the tech details online, but it has them all, aperture priority, manual focus, video, sepia, and a million special effects. It has a 12 mega-pixel MOS sensor which is way better (technical term) in low light than other previous sensors. I would compare it to a 16 or 18 megapixel sensor which in my opinion is just overkill. I don't know why, but I can take many low light shots without a flash and get realistic definition and color. Autofocus could be a bit faster, but I really can't complain since I use the heck out of my cameras and expect them to survive under the abuse I put them through all over the globe. For most folks, you won't even notice the extra millisecond or so . I'm using a class 10 64GB SD card in mine and it seems to work fine. My older ZS3 P&S can't hold a candle (sorry) to this ZS50.
The camera does not come with an external battery charger. You have to plug the camera into line voltage to recharge - this always makes me a bit nervous.given the sensitive electronics in the camera and the sad state of the US power grid. I bought an external charger with two batteries and a car charger from Wasabi which is also sold on Amazon. I have no affiliation with Wasabi and no profit motive. I'm sure other chargers are just as good. Finally, the ZS50 has WiFi as well as cables.

If you need a medium price, pocket size P&S with tons of capability and a battery saving VIEW FINDER EYEPIECE, this is a great choice.

Not at my DSLR quality but then again I don't have to carry 8 different lenses.  Decent all around camera for the price.  I first got the Sony RX100 but had to return it do to the limited zoom. column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column11:
Everything I was hoping it would be. Easy to use, great features, unbelievable zoom and picture quality. Excellent low light pictures, perfect size, intuitive operation, great battery life, great macro shots, great image stabilization.

Haven't tried time lapse or real dark night shots yet but 240 fps is pretty decent but wish the quality were a little higher in this mode.

Small minuses, video section not as intuitive, took some getting used to until it was intuitive, Aperture range on the small side so not much you can do with depth or shutter speeds in manual mode.

One additional feature I've never seen in any of the ad copy for this camera is the digital zoom can go up to 120x and it's useful!!.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: This is an awesome camera. I think some of the negative reviews ...
column11: This is an awesome camera.  I think some of the negative reviews are from people that don't take the time to learn how to use it correctly.  I was one of those people until I spent a ton of time going through the manual and playing with the camera to see what different settings do.  An example of something that I learned that made a huge difference when using the semi auto (Shutter Speed or Aperture) settings, is what to do with your flash settings when taking outdoor pictures.  If you are manually setting your shutter speed, and  flash is set to Auto, it will never tell you that that speed won't work.  You could set it on 1/2000 and it will stay white (setting OK) because it believes the flash will fix it. The flash can't light up the whole outdoors!!  Turn you flash off,  and it will go Red if you set the shutter speed to fast.  This is just one example of inappropriate settings causing bad pictures.  The zoom on this camera is incredible.  I posted two pictures taken from the same spot.  One no zoom, the other fully zoomed (optical + digital 120x total) in on a toy that is in the middle of the first picture.  Pictures were taken with no tripod. It is beyond what I thought zoom could do on a compact camera!

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column11: Sort of pissed me off that there is only one option for low resolution photos on aspect ratio! One would thing this day and age they could make resolution and aspect ratios separate choices, I mean how hard can that be? But NO, now I have to go through several extra steps in my daily job to reduce the photo resolution for the aspect ratio I need - a royal pain in the but and I would NOT have bought the camera if I had known that!! Also the auto function stinks, often times not producing proper colors, some very magenta or very orange, and sometimes taking taking series of pictures when I only want one! Also the location of the flash stinks, because if you try to use one handed your hand naturally covers the flash! VERY POOR DESIGN!

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column11: I like cameras with viewfinders, and this is one of the few point-and-shoots with one. (Yes, it is electronic, not optical, but it works fine for me.) I also really appreciate the 30x optical zoom. It is compact enough to fit in a jacket pocket, so I can carry it around with me, although it is not as small as a Sony DSCHX90V I compared it too. But the Sony was way too fiddly to use easily, for me at least. I dinged it one start for two reasons: I could never get the WiFi transfer of photos to work with my Mac, although it works fine to my iPad. And I wish it had a larger sensor, although with only 12 MP instead of the more usual 18, it is better than it would be otherwise. The low-light images are just fine.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: Died after 3 months; "Irreparable" to Panasonic support
column11:
I bought this camera for travel and through my first couple trips I was really excited about the images. I'm not much of a photographer yet and this let me take better quality photos at the point and shoot level and got me excited about learning more and more about my camera without shelling out for a dslr and with having the ease of a smaller camera that can fit into any purse and most jacket pockets.
I bought the camera June 23, 2015 and I currently (Oct 10,2015) have a lovely little brick that does nothing. After repeatedly poorer and poorer sensitivity, the power button quit working on me. I could turn the camera on by taking out the battery and the putting it back in (yes, the battery is fully charged), but the power button will not turn on the camera. I sent it in to Panasonic support and found out today that the camera was water-damaged. WHAT!? There were a few extremely humid times that we used it and once in a very light drizzle, but water damage is not something that ever ever ever remotely crossed my mind. So my only options after 3 months of using a $350 camera is to pay $280 for a replacement. Nothing they can do to fix it. Nothing. It's apparently a brick now. Super disappointed in apparently the fragility of this camera and Panasonic support. I would never recommend them.
As mentioned in other reviews, the ink on my mode dial also completely wiped off after the few months of use. Not a huge problem because you can use the screen to see which setting you are on, but still... a small indicator of the lack of thought that was put into this camera.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: Great Camera with some minor disappointments
column11: I bought this camera mainly because I needed a "pocketable" with a good zoom to use for the photography I do for my oil paintings.  The display is absolutely stunning and so much easier to see outdoors than my Sony RX1002 or my Canon G11.  The 30x optical zoom and the image stabilization is amazing.  I also love that it shoots in RAW format, the wifi feature set up very easily with my iPhone, it's controls are easy to understand and navigate, and it has an "on board" HDR, which is also very useful for my art.  Overall, I am very satisfied and I think the price was quite reasonable.  I do have a few disappointments:  the exposure range for bracketing and for the HDR seems too narrow and I can't find anyway to adjust it (my Sony RX1002 does a much better job with these features).  The camera is very light weight (which is good) but compared to my Sony and my Canon it feels "cheap" and more likely to break.  I've already had one incident where the lens cover wouldn't open upon deployment and I had to gently pry it open with my finger.  Also, this Panasonic just doesn't seem to be as "robust" as my Sony RX1002--not as many features, settings, adjustments, etc.  --almost feels a bit "toy like".  Overall, I do not have "buyer's remorse" and will certainly be using it.  But I'm not sure it will replace my other cameras, which means I will probably be walking around with two pocketables!  If only my Sony had a 30x optical zoom!!!

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column11: Have had the ZS50'a few weeks now..Takes great pictures and has many useful features. Great Travel Camera that has to be one of the best ultra zoom compacts on the market if not the best,!

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: The perfect travel camera that has become my everyday camera!
column11:
Let me begin by saying that I do have some experience in photography. I own MANY cameras, from Hasselblads to an 8X10 view camera. I have numerous 35mm SLRs, and a couple of very nice DSLRs. I have taught photography at both a high school and at a community college. What I'm saying is that I do have a background on which to base my review!

I bought this camera for travel, hoping I could leave my bulkier cameras home. Well, home they are staying! This camera will work perfectly for my vacation needs, with the incredible extra advantage of being pocketable!

Okay, this isn't something a pro would use for an important shoot. But it comes close to matching my Canon T1i in image quality, and has FAR better video capability. I normally carry the Canon wherever I go, but now I just stick the ZS50 in my pocket.

The long zoom, the viewfinder, and the ability to shoot in RAW are what drew me to this camera. It's a very nice little package, and I expect to take several thousand pictures on my vacation. If I have any further comments, I'll add this to this review.

If you are looking for a nice, compact, high-quality point-and-shoot, buy this!
ONE IMPORTANT NOTE: If you do buy this camera, be VERY careful when you insert the semi-proprietary USB cable into it to charge the camera battery or transfer pictures to your computer (I bought an external charger and extra batteries, but still use the cable on occasion). It would be very easy to damage the plug in the camera if the cable isn't inserted in exactly the right orientation. This is the only shortcoming I've noticed thus far, but it isn't enough to tarnish any of the five stars!

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: Be prepared to pay an extra $170+ to make this camera usable for anything but an occasional picture.
column11: This is my fourth Panasonic camera.  I have always been happy with them before.  I thought  that I was replacing my ZS-20 with an updated model with more zoom.  Instead I got a camera made in China with a battery and no battery charger.  The battery instructions were to charge it inside the camera.  I could not find a battery charger so I contacted Panasonic.  Only a replacement battery - no charger.  I did an on-line chat.  The rep did give me links to a battery charger that needed a cable, sold separately, and the battery.  In camera charging does not work for me because I often use three or four batteries a day during trips.  I had to spend another close to $200 just for 2 batteries, a charger and a cable just to be able to use this camera effectively.  I don't even know if this will solve the problem.  The extra zoom is hard to focus.  I don't know if it is just getting used to a new camera.  I think not.  I also called and spoke to a rep who kept saying she was sorry for the inconvenience.  I did not have this problem with previous Panasonic cameras.

column10: Lettering on mode dial faded and disappeared
column11:
Just a quick note to caution buyers that there is a fair chance that the lettering on the mode dial on the top of the camera will wear off. The mode dial lets you switch to such settings as automatic, program, aperture priority, shutter priority, scene, panorama, etc. I bought my ZS50 in May and by a month later the lettering had faded and disappeared during my normal daily use. The Panasonic support people were little help. They acknowledged that the problem is a "known issue" to Panasonic. But all he did was say I should send it to their McAllen,
Texas, repair center. I was given no info on whether the problem was correctable, how long I would have to do without my camera, or any assurance that the same problem wouldn't recur even if they "fixed" it or gave me a new camera. If you get a ZS50 with this problem, you can determine what mode you are in by looking at the monitor screen, but you will no longer just be able to look at the mode dial to see what setting you are in. By the way, it's a good camera.

column2: Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZS50K 30X Travel Zoom with Eye Viewfinder (Black)
column10: What I also liked-- Takes good quality photos and videos
column11:
I wanted a compact camera that had a viewfinder. I was tired of trying to see what was displayed on an LCD screen on a bright day or whenever the lighting conditions made it difficult. It does had an LCD as well and what is clever is that you can set it so the LCD automatically shuts down when you place your eye next to the viewfinder.
What I also liked--
Takes good quality photos and videos. No comparison to the photo's on an iphone 6, especially in low light or when you want to use the zoom; which is optically engineered (unlike smartphones that simply enlarge the captured image).. no contest here hands down better than any smartphone.
1. Fairly light-- You can carry it easily in a cargo pants pocket but not in a jeans pocket.
2. Very long zoom range-- from wide angle to 25+ zoom with optical image stabilization
3. Many manual controls for those who have photographic backgrounds or a intelligent auto mode for those who do not.
4. Wifi and smartphone app --if you like your images transferred to your smartphone or control your camera completely through the smartphone, you can do so with an app.

What I don't like:
The panorama mode creates images that are fuzzy. They are also timed. I think it actually creates a video and saves it as an image; and it will time out if you don't move it fast enough. You are better off creating your panoramas manually by taking 3-5 separate photos and stitching them together using photo editing software. This isn't convenient though. I

Nice rear monitor and a surprisingly good EVF. I expected better low light performance due to the 12.1 megapixel sensor. But the low pixel count just served to limit the resolution of the pictures taken. Try to zoom in and examine a photo, and the missing resolution is readily apparent.
